contentrichtext.text: [[Image:OlafDreyer1.JPG|thumb|Olaf Dreyer at Harvard University]] '''Olaf Dreyer''' (born 1969 in Hamburg) is a German [[theoretical physicist]] and postdoctoral fellow in the Department of Applied Mathematics at the [[University of Waterloo]] whose research interests include [[quantum gravity]] and the [[quantum measurement problem]]. Dreyer received his Ph.D. in quantum gravity in 2001 from the [[Pennsylvania State University]]<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.houghtonmifflinbooks.com/booksellers/press_release/smolin/#physicists | title = Press release for "The Trouble with Physics" published by Houghton Mifflin Company : Hot Young Physicists | accessdate = 22 January 2011 }}</ref> under the direction of [[Abhay Ashtekar]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Baez | first = John | title = This Week's Finds in Mathematical Physics (Week 189) | year = 2002 | url = http://math.ucr.edu/home/baez/week189.html | accessdate = 22 January 2011 }}</ref> Subsequently he has held a postdoctoral fellowship at the [[Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics]] in [[Waterloo, Ontario]], a Marie Curie Fellowship at [[Imperial College]], London, and a postdoctoral fellowship at the Center for Theoretical Physics, [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]. In 2002 Dreyer proposed<ref>{{citation | title = Quasinormal Modes, the Area Spectrum, and Black Hole Entropy | last = Dreyer | first = Olaf | journal = Phys. Rev. Lett. | volume = 90 | pages = 081301 | year = 2003 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.90.081301 | id = | pmid=12633415 | arxiv=arXiv:gr-qc/0211076v1 | bibcode=2003PhRvL..90h1301D }}</ref> a connection between the [[Immirzi parameter|Barbero-Immirzi parameter]] in [[loop quantum gravity]] and the asymptotic behaviour of [[black hole]] quasinormal modes (in numerical general relativity), building on previous insights due to Shahar Hod.<ref>{{citation | title = Bohr's Correspondence Principle and The Area Spectrum of Quantum Black Holes | last = Hod | first = Shahar | journal = Phys. Rev. Lett. | volume = 81 | pages = 4293 | year = 1998 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.81.4293 | id = | arxiv=arXiv:gr-qc/9812002v2 | bibcode=1998PhRvL..81.4293H }}</ref> Subsequently, [[Lubos Motl]] proved that the exact asymptotic behaviour of the quasinormal modes of the Schwarzschild black hole was as predicted numerically.<ref>{{citation | title = An analytical computation of asymptotic Schwarzschild quasinormal frequencies | last = Motl | first = Lubos | journal = Adv. Theor. Math. Phys. | volume = 6 | year = 2003 | pages = 1135â€“1162 | id = | arxiv=arXiv:gr-qc/0212096v3 }}</ref> Dreyer has developed an approach to quantum gravity known as "internal relativity".<ref>{{citation | title = Knowing the mind of God: Seven theories of everything | last = Marshall | first = Michael | date = 4 March 2010 | journal = New Scientist | url = http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn18612-knowing-the-mind-of-god-seven-theories-of-everything.html }}</ref> ==Notes== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{cite web | url = http://www.rle.mit.edu/xqit/dreyer-abstract.html | title = xQIT:: Center for Extreme Quantum Information Theory at MIT] | accessdate = 22 January 2011 }} * {{citation | title = It's all relative | last = Becker | first = Kate | year = 2007 | publisher = The Foundational Questions Institute | url = http://fqxi.org/community/articles | accessdate = 22 January 2011 }} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Dreyer, Olaf | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1969 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Hamburg, Germany | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dreyer, Olaf}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:German physicists]] [[Category:University of Waterloo faculty]] [[Category:1969 births]] {{Germany-scientist-stub}}
